Running the Batteries[Allusion][Military] During the American Civil war, a battery was an emplacement of artillery. Light batteries were usually made up of six light cannon, each on a two-wheeled carriage and hitched to a two-wheeled ammunition cart called a limber. The entire assembly was normally pulled by six horses. Heavy artillery batteries were made up of varying numbers of permanent or semi-permanent cannon. Both types seem to have been in use at the defense of Vicksburg.
(R.D. Madison).

As observed from an anchorage[Allusion][Nautical] An anchorage required depth to keep vessels afloat, room for them to swing with wind and current, and protection from storms. In this case, the anchorage also protected the fleet from the batteries downstream.
(R.D. Madison) above Vicksburgh[Allusion][Historical] Usually spelled Vicksburg, a city on the Mississippi about 250 miles below Memphis and 200 miles above New Orleans (by land). Union forces planned to divide the Confederacy by controlling the Mississippi River from its confluence with the Ohio to the Gulf of Mexico. The high bluffs of Vicksburg allowed the city to hold out the longest; Vicksburg’s fall to a six-week siege following the events of this poem and the fall of Port Hudson opened the river for the free passage of union vessels.
(R.D. Madison).
We felt the dew, and seemed to feel The secret like a burden laid. The first boat melts; and a second keel Is blent with the foliaged shade— Their midnight rounds have the rebel officers made?

Unspied as yet. A third—a fourth— Gun-boat and transport[Allusion] [Nautical] Gun-boats were specially designed or converted to withstand the shock of firing a heavy gun and to resist, by means of heavy timber or armor plate, bombardment from shore or another vessel. Transports had little such extra protection and hence were more vulnerable.
(R.D. Madison) in Indian file[Allusion] One after another.
(R.D. Madison)
[Intratextual] Melville alludes to Native Americans often in Battle-Pieces, mobilizing familiar caricatures as metaphors in his poems. See also "Apathy and Enthusiasm", "Lyon", "Donelson", "The Armies of the Wilderness", "The College Colonel", and "The Scout Toward Aldie."
(Eric Meckley) Upon the war-path, smooth from the North; But the watch may they hope to beguile? The manned river-batteries stretch for mile on mile.

Converging firesMassing cannon fire on a single target was more effective than firing individual guns at separate targets.
(R.D. Madison). We speak, though low: “That blastful furnace can they thread?” “Why, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego Came out all right, we readOld Testament Book of Daniel 3.13-28. Nebuchadnezzar casts these three into a burning fiery furnace for failing to worship a golden image. They are saved from burning by an angel “like a son of the gods” and Nebuchadnezzar is converted.
(R.D. Madison); The Lord, be sure, he helps his people, NedStanton Garner reads this as a nod to Ned Curtis, Melville's cousin who served in the navy at the Battle of Vicksburg.
(Garner, The Civil War World of Herman Melville... p. 231).”

How we strain our gaze. On bluffs they shun A golden growing flame appears— Confirms to a silvery steadfast one: “The town is afire!” crows Hugh: “three cheers!” Lot stops his mouth: “Nay, lad, better three tears.”
How dread to mark her near the glare And glade of death the beacon throws Athwart the racing waters there; One by one each plainer grows, Then speeds a blazoned target to our gladdened foes.

The impartial cresset lights[definition] Torches set up on shore
(R. D. Madison) as well The fixed forts to the boats that run; And, plunged from the ports, their answers swell Back to each fortress dun[definition] Can refer to both the dull color in the semi-light or the position of the forts on hills.
(R.D. Madison): Ponderous words speaks every monster gun.
Fearless they flash through gates of flame, The salamanders hard to hit, Though vivid shows each bulky frame; And never the batteries intermit, Nor the boats huge guns; they fire and flit.
Anon a lull. The beacon dies: “Are they out of that strait accurst?” But other flames now dawning rise, Not mellowly brilliant like the first, But rolled in smoke, whose whitish volumes burst.
A baleful brand, a hurrying torch Whereby anew the boats are seen— A burning transport all alurch! Breathless we gaze; yet still we glean Glimpses of beauty as we eager lean.

The effulgence takes an amber glow Which bathes the hill-side villas far; Affrighted ladies mark the show Painting the pale magnolia— The fair, false, Circe light of cruel War[Allusion] [literary] In Homer’s Odyssey (Sealts #278 and [in part] #147), Circe turns mortals into beasts; here, the image is of the transformative effect of firelight... (R. D. Madison) which reveals the change from men to beasts that war precipitates. (Eric Meckley).

The barge drifts doomed, a plague-struck one. Shoreward in yawls[allusion] [nautical] A round-bottomed boat propelled by about a dozen oarsmen, here used as lifeboats. (R. D. Madison) the sailors fly. But the gauntlet now is nearly run, The spleenful forts by fits reply, And the burning boat dies down in morning's sky.

All out of range. Adieu, Messieurs! Jeers, as it speeds, our parting gun. So burst we through their barriers And menaces every one: So Porter proves himself a brave man's son[allusion] [intratext] [intertext] 77 Porter] David Dixon Porter (1813-1891). Melville’s note "g" is a reminder that he had plundered the elder Porter’s Journal of a Cruise (Bercaw #563) in Typee and “The Encantadas.”.
